qas.question: When did Wallace and Darwin unveil the theory of evolution?
What was there a rush to do with the theory of evolution?

answers.text: bring it into the social sciences

qas.question: What organization was Broca in the process of disentangling himself from?
What did the French call evolutionism?
Who unveiled evolution in the 18th century?
Who broke away from the Societe d'Anthropologie de Paris?
Who formed the Societe de biologie?

plausible_answers.text: "the study of the human group, considered as a whole, in its details, and in relation to the rest of nature"

qas.question: What did Broca redefine Transformisme to?

context: <b5_0>Darwin and Wallace<b5_0/> unveiled evolution in the <a0_0>late 1850s.<a0_0/> There was an immediate rush to <a1_0>bring it into the social sciences<a1_0/>. <b6_0><b7_0>Paul Broca<b7_0/><b6_0/> in <a2_0>Paris<a2_0/> was in the process of breaking away from the <a3_0>Société de biologie<a3_0/> to form the first of the explicitly anthropological societies, the Société d'Anthropologie de Paris, meeting for the first time in Paris in 1859.[n 4] When he read Darwin he became an immediate convert to <a4_0>Transformisme<a4_0/>, as the French called evolutionism. His definition now became <b8_0>"the study of the human group, considered as a whole, in its details, and in relation to the rest of nature"<b8_0/>.
